de.mrapp.android.dialog

Class EditTextDialog

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.app.Dialog
      • de.mrapp.android.dialog.AbstractMaterialDialog
        • de.mrapp.android.dialog.AbstractHeaderDialog
          • de.mrapp.android.dialog.AbstractAnimateableDialog
            • de.mrapp.android.dialog.AbstractValidateableDialog
              • de.mrapp.android.dialog.AbstractButtonBarDialog
                • de.mrapp.android.dialog.EditTextDialog
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.content.DialogInterface, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener, android.view.Window.Callback, AnimateableDialog, AnimateableDialogDecorator, ButtonBarDialog, ButtonBarDialogDecorator, Dialog, EditTextDialogDecorator, HeaderDialog, HeaderDialogDecorator, MaterialDialog, MaterialDialogDecorator, ValidateableDialog, ValidateableDialogDecorator, de.mrapp.android.validation.Validateable<java.lang.CharSequence>

    public class EditTextDialog
extends AbstractButtonBarDialog
implements EditTextDialogDecorator
    A dialog, which is designed according to Android 5's Material Design guidelines even on pre-Lollipop devices and contains an EditText widget. Such a dialog consists of a title, a message and said EditText widget. Optionally, up to three buttons can be shown.

    For creating or showing such dialogs, the methods EditTextDialog#create() or EditTextDialog#show() of the builder EditTextDialog.Builder can be used.

    Since:
    5.1.0
    Author:
    Michael Rapp

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  EditTextDialog.Builder
      A builder, which allows to create and show dialogs, which are designed according to Android 5's Material Design guidelines even on pre-Lollipop devices and allow to indicate a running progress.

      • EditTextDialog

        protected EditTextDialog(@NonNull
                         android.content.Context context,
                         @StyleRes
                         int themeResourceId)
        Creates a dialog, which is designed according to Android 5's Material Design guidelines even on pre-Lollipop devices and contains an EditText widget.
        Parameters:
        context - The context, which should be used by the dialog, as an instance of the class Context. The context may not be null
        themeResourceId - The resource id of the theme, which should be used by the dialog, as an Integer value. The resource id must correspond to a valid theme
